articles.headline: Speech Gives Climate Goals Center Stage
articles.snippet: Democrats said the president would begin an aggressive campaign to address the issue, using his executive powers to sidestep Congressional opposition.
articles.abstract: Democrats said the president would begin an aggressive campaign to address the issue, using his executive powers to sidestep Congressional opposition.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — President Obama made addressing climate change the most prominent policy vow of his second Inaugural Address, setting in motion what Democrats say will be a deliberately paced but aggressive campaign built around the use of his executive powers to sidestep Congressional opposition.
articles.byline: By Richard W. Stevenson and John M. Broder

articles.headline: With Tax Advantages Looking Shaky, Private Equity Seeks a New Path
articles.snippet: The private equity industry is discussing how to respond to a new reality: its long-held tax advantages are likely to disappear.
articles.abstract: The private equity industry is discussing how to respond to a new reality: its long-held tax advantages are likely to disappear.
articles.lead_paragraph: As Washington grapples with the country’s fiscal woes, the private equity industry is grudgingly facing a new reality: its long-held tax advantages are likely to disappear.

articles.headline: Early Sales Tempered With Caution at Sundance
articles.snippet: Although the independent film business is healthier than in years, the vast majority of the feature films at this year’s festival won’t recoup production costs.
articles.abstract: Although the independent film business is healthier than in years, the vast majority of the feature films at this year’s festival won’t recoup production costs.
articles.lead_paragraph: PARK CITY, Utah — After the premiere of a documentary called “Twenty Feet From Stardom” at the Sundance Film Festival here on Thursday, the movie’s director, Morgan Neville, shared a blunt anecdote with the crowd.

articles.headline: China’s Focus on Aerospace Raises Security Questions
articles.snippet: As Beijing’s leaders try to find new ways to invest $3 trillion of foreign reserves, aerospace deals prove attractive even as they give China’s neighbors a reason to wonder about security threats.
articles.abstract: As Beijing’s leaders try to find new ways to invest $3 trillion of foreign reserves, aerospace deals prove attractive even as they give China’s neighbors a reason to wonder about security threats.
articles.lead_paragraph: TIANJIN, China — When Airbus executives arrived here seven years ago scouting for a location to assemble passenger jets, the broad, flat expanse next to Tianjin Binhai International Airport was a grassy field.

articles.headline: LEDs Emerge as a Popular ‘Green’ Lighting
articles.snippet: Consumers are buying more LEDs, but over time, the long-lasting bulbs will result in fewer sales, making the race for market share all the more urgent.
articles.abstract: Consumers are buying more LEDs, but over time, the long-lasting bulbs will result in fewer sales, making the race for market share all the more urgent.
articles.lead_paragraph: The lighting industry has finally come up with an energy-efficient replacement for the standard incandescent bulb that people actually seem to like: the LED bulb.

articles.headline: Prophecies Made in Davos Don’t Always Come True
articles.snippet: Many influential people will gather this week at the World Economic Forum to make predictions, and some of them will be right, and some wrong.
articles.abstract: Many influential people will gather this week at the World Economic Forum to make predictions, and some of them will be right, and some wrong.
articles.lead_paragraph: You’re going to be hearing a lot of predictions over the next several days. Be leery.

articles.headline: Even if It Enrages Your Boss, Social Net Speech Is Protected
articles.snippet: Federal regulators are ordering employers to scale back policies that limit what workers can say online.
articles.abstract: Federal regulators are ordering employers to scale back policies that limit what workers can say online.
articles.lead_paragraph: As Facebook and Twitter become as central to workplace conversation as the company cafeteria, federal regulators are ordering employers to scale back policies that limit what workers can say online.

articles.headline: Japan’s Bond-Buying Plan Quickly Meets Criticism
articles.snippet: The Bank of Japan set an ambitious 2 percent inflation target and pledged to ease monetary policy but there are doubts about just how much of an effect the moves will have.
articles.abstract: The Bank of Japan set an ambitious 2 percent inflation target and pledged to ease monetary policy but there are doubts about just how much of an effect the moves will have.
articles.lead_paragraph: Another central bank, another round of unconventional monetary policy.
articles.byline: By Nelson D. Schwartz and Hiroko Tabuchi

articles.headline: Tepid Vote for Netanyahu in Israel Is Seen as Rebuke
articles.snippet: Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu of Israel is likely to serve a third term, but voters gave a surprising second place to a centrist party founded by a celebrity who emphasized kitchen-table issues.
articles.abstract: Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu of Israel is likely to serve a third term, but voters gave a surprising second place to a centrist party founded by a celebrity who emphasized kitchen-table issues.
articles.lead_paragraph: TEL AVIV — A weakened Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu emerged Wednesday from Israel’s national election likely to serve a third term,  after voters on Tuesday gave a surprising second place to a new centrist party founded by a television celebrity who emphasized kitchen-table issues like class size and apartment prices.

articles.headline: At Bolshoi, Regrets and a New Appointment
articles.snippet: The Bolshoi Ballet has made Galina Stepanenko, a former principal dancer, its acting artistic director. She takes over for Sergei Filin, who after suffering an acid attack, said that he regretted not accepting protection.
articles.abstract: The Bolshoi Ballet has made Galina Stepanenko, a former principal dancer, its acting artistic director. She takes over for Sergei Filin, who after suffering an acid attack, said that he regretted not accepting protection.
articles.lead_paragraph: MOSCOW — Galina Stepanenko, a former principal dancer with the Bolshoi Ballet, was named the company’s acting artistic director on Tuesday, taking over for Sergei Filin, who was severely burned last week when a masked man threw acid in his face. In an interview published on Tuesday, Mr. Filin said he regretted not accepting protection after receiving threats in mid-December.
articles.byline: By Sophia Kishkovsky and Ellen Barry
